body:
https://github.com/protocolbuffers/protobuf/blob/main/docs/field_presence.md

Looks like we need to make channels `optional` in the protobuf definition, and also change the protofier to detect the presence.

body:
> High level programming language with abstracted number type system supporting these special values usually consider them as special float or double type. However, in low level programming language like C we don't have these values.

I don't think this is accurate. `NaN`, the infinities, and signed zeros are all part of the IEEE 754 floating point specification, which these days is usually implemented at a hardware level. You can [check yourself](https://codapi.org/embed/?sandbox=gcc&code=data%3A%3Bbase64%2CU87MS84pTUlVsCkuScnM18uw4%2BLKzCtRyE3MzNPQVKjmUlAoKMrMK0nTUFJNi8lT0lEw0DPQN9Az0LTGlDLELaWLLFeUWlJalKdgYM1VCwA%3D) in the C playground.

I don't see any indication in the protobuf documentation that these values aren't supported. The serialization for doubles is just a fixed-length 64-bit field, and there are bit patterns that unambiguously represent each of these.
Looks like I misread the protobuf doc - it says when serializing proto object to JSON, NaN and infinity are not as numeric values, and will instead be encoded as string.
